awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Development of a zeolite filter to dry biomass in an energy efficient, cost effective, and gentle manner
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to develop a novel method of drying agricultural products that is more energy efficient than current commercial devices and preserves the nutritional value of the dried products. This project is based upon  fast dehydration of wet biomass using desiccants comprised of particles of a certain size and arrangement. According to preliminary trials, this method may be 10 times more energy efficient than other drying methods. This project will produce a reusable particle filter that can be used to efficiently dehydrate food and agricultural products. This drying method can preserve nutritional value within the US food system while simultaneously reducing production costs, make agricultural industries more economically viable, and be easily powered by renewable energy sources thereby reducing fossil fuel consumption within the food industry.

The technical innovation of this STTR Phase I project is the development of efficient and effective drying methods for agricultural products.  The technology is based on the incorporation of zeolite particles onto a substrate while maintaining their porosity. In order to achieve rapid dehydration of wet matter, the zeolite must be small in size and supported on a substrate so that its surface retains functionality. This methodology requires careful chemical synthesis. The key research goals are to conjugate or physically bind zeolite particles to a porous substrate, maintain the accessible surface area of the zeolite, and create a new material that can endure many cycles of brief low-power microwave heating to accomplish dehydration. In this project, several approaches will be investigated, starting with the synthesis of porous substrates, then modifying the surface to contain a controlled number of chemical functional groups, and then coating the substrate with zeolite using covalent linkages. In addition to covalent monolayer linkages, the project will also aim to optimize substrate coverage using other binding mechanisms such as hydrogen bonding.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
We developed a novel drying technology that is more energy efficient than current options and preserves the nutritional value of the dried product. The heart of the technology is a material formed from a type of desiccant called zeolites. Zeolites can be naturally occurring or synthesized minerals made up mainly of aluminum and silicon compounds, and are widely used commercially as drying agents, in air and water purifiers, and other industrial uses.

The innovation: Desiccants made of zeolite have been used for dehydration purposes in a variety of manners, but previously existing methods do not afford either desired rates of water removal or regeneration of zeolite in energy saving manners. Our work creates a material that can be used in commercial settings for rapid hydration and dehydration in a way that was not possible before. 

In our material, the zeolites are fused together in such a way that optimizes porosity for rapid hydration (to remove moisture in the environment) and dehydration (to regenerate zeolites). The fusion will be strong enough for commercial use and to withstand multiple cycles of microwaves for regeneration. The novel material is assembled into a filter via stackable bricks of material, which makes the filter system scalable depending on the volume of biomass or other commodities to be dried. The filter (?ZD Filter?) can be connected to a machine or container that holds the target biomass.

Our goal under the NSF SBIR Phase I grant was to investigate several approaches to achieve robust chemical or physical conjugation to support microwavable zeolite particles on substrates. We expected that we would create an entirely new material that can be used for rapid dehydration of wet matter. During our work in Phase I, we realized we did not need a permanent substrate. Instead, we were able to use sacrificial templates that, once burned away, left a porous noodle-like structure of randomly aggregated zeolite particles with an adjustable hierarchical porosity. We then connect the noodles using structural and microwaveable fibers to create the complete material that meets all the requirements for commercial drying of commodities, including seaweed.

During Phase I, we tested this material for its hydration and dehydration properties, as well as used the ZD Filter to dry two different species of seaweed provided by domestic seaweed farms. The new material was found to be superior to existing desiccants such as millimeter-sized zeolite spherical beads: it has a 35% faster rate of hydration (without capacity correction, and 2x as fast after such correction), and a 4-5x faster dehydration rate than existing desiccants. The former saves time, and the latter directly leads to energy saving.

The ZD Filter can therefore be used to efficiently remove water from commodities like seaweed, and it can be regenerated for reuse using microwaves for rapid and energy efficient dehydration. To test, wet seaweed provided by BLU3 and Symbrosia were dried using the filter materials, and the results are shown in Figure 1. For comparison, sun drying and oven drying of the same batch of seaweed were conducted. It is shown that seaweed dried by the filter in vacuum without pumping during the drying can be completed within 40 minutes, slightly better than sun drying and oven drying (105 ?C for an hour) (Figure 1C). All drying was conducted using both a single layer and clumps of seaweed leaves. These results show that it is possible to employ the potential filter to successfully dry seaweed in a controlled environment (important for food safety and pharmaceutical uses, as well as for US seaweed farms located in New England and the Pacific Northwest) without requiring any sacrifice of time compared to the slowest drying method (sun drying).

Figure 1:

Seaweed before and after sun drying (BLU3; the fresh seaweed is shown in the left and dried on the right). B) results of drying using the filter (Symbrosia, fresh is shown on the left and dried on the right. C) sun drying and ZD Filter results. The top panel shows the comparison of sun drying (+), oven drying (red ◄) and ZD Filter (all other symbols) of seaweed from BLU3 and the bottom panel shows the results of sun drying on different days (+ and ?) and ZD Filter (■) of seaweed from Symbrosia. D) data from panel C processed to display moisture content assuming oven dried (105 ?C for an hour) to be completely dried in top panel for BLU3 seaweed and terminal sun dried to be completely dried in bottom panel for Symbrosia seaweed. The top panel shows the comparison of sun drying on different days (+ and ?) and ZD Filter (all other symbols) of seaweed from BLU3 and the bottom panel shows the results of sun drying on different days (● and ▲) and ZD Filter (◆) of seaweed from Symbrosia.


Last Modified: 10/07/2023
Modified by: Jennifer Goggin
